I have dig'd a grave, all buried in a wife;
For thee I have defi'd my constant Mistris,
That never fail'd her servant, glorious war;
For thee, refus'd the fellowship of an Order
Which Princes through all dangers have been proud
To fetch as far as from Jerusalem:
And am I thus rewarded?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.l: By all goodnesse,
You wrong my Lady, and deserve her not,
When you are at your best: repent your rashnesse,
Twil show well in you.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Do, and aske her pardon.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: No, I have liv'd too long, to have my faith
(My tri'd faith) call'd in question, and by him
That should know true affection is too tender
To suffer an unkind touch, without ruine;
Study ingratitude, all, from my example;
For to be thankfull now, is to be false.
But be it so, let me die, I see you wish it;
Yet dead for truth, and pities sake, report
What weapon you made choice of, when you kild me.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.l: She faints,

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: What have ye done?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: My last breath cannot
Be better spent, then to say I forgive you;
Nor is my death untimely, since with me
I take along, what might have been hereafter
In scorn delivered for the doubtfull issue
Of a suspected mother.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.l: Oh, she's gone.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: For ever gone. Are you a man?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: I grow here.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Open her mouth, and powre this Cordiall in it;
If any spark of life be unquench'd in her,
This will recover her.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.l: Tis all in vain,
She's stiffe already: live I, and she dead?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: How like a murtherer I stand? look up,
And heare me curse my selfe, or but behold
The vengance I wilt take for't Oriana,
And then in peace forsake me: Jealousie,
Thou loathsome vomit of the fiends below,
What desperate hunger made me to receive thee
Into my heart, and soule? I let thee forth,
And so in death finde ease; and do's ray fault then
Deserve no greater punishment? no, Ile live
To keep thee for a fury to torment me,
And make me know what hell is on the earth:
All joyes and hopes forsake me; all mens malice,
And all the plagues they can inflict, I wish it
Fall thick upon me: Let my teares be laught at,
And may my enemies smile to heare me groane,
And dead, may I be pitied of none. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pray you sir why was the Ordnance of the Fort Discharg'd so sodainly?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Twas the Governours pleasure,
In honour of the Dane, a custome us'd,
To speake a Souldiers welcome.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Tis a fit one:
But is my Master here too?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Three daies since.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Might I demand without offence, so much,
Is't pride in him (however now a slave)
That I am not admitted to his presence?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: His curtesie to you, and to mankind
May easily resolve you, he is free
From that poore vice which onely empty men
Esteem a vertue.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What's the reason then,
As you imagine, sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Why I will tell you;
You are a woman of a tempting beauty,
And he, however vertuous, as a man
Subject to humane frailties; and how far
They may prevaile upon him, should he see you,
He is not ignorant: and therefore chooses,
With care t'avoyd the cause that may produce
Some strange effect, which wil not well keep ranck
With the rare temperance, which is admired
In his life hitherto.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: This much increases
My strong desire to see him.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: It should rather
Teach you to thank the Prophet that you worship,
That you are such a mans, who though he may
Do any thing which youth and heat of blood
Invites him to, yet dares not give way to them:
Your entertainment's Noble, and not like
Your present fortune; and it all those teares
Which made grief lovely in you, in the relation
Of the sad story, that forc'd me to weep too,
Your husbands hard fate were not counterfeit;
You should rejoyce that you have means to pay
A chast life to his memory, and bring to him
Those sweets, which while he liv'd he could not taste of:
But if you wantonly bestow them on
Another man, you offer violence
To him, though dead; and his griev'd spirit will suffer
For your immodest loosnesse.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Why, I hope sir,
My willingnesse to looke on him, to whom
I owe my life and service, is no proofe
Of any unchast purpose.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: So I wish too,
And in the confidence it is not, Lady,
I dare the better tell you he will see you
This night, in which by him I am commanded,
To bring you to his chamber; to what end
I easily should guesse, were I Miranda;
And therefore, though I can yeild little reason,
(But in a generall love to womens goodnesse)
Why I should be so tender of your honour,
I willingly would bestow some counsaile of you,
And would you follow it?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Let me first heare it,
And then I can resolve you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: My advice then
Is, that you would not, (as most Ladies use
When they prepare themselves for such encounters)
Study to adde, by artificiall dressings
To native excellence; yours (without help)
But seen as it is now, would make a Hermit
Leave his deaths head, & change his after hopes
Of endlesse comforts for a few short minutes
Of present pleasures; to prevent which, Lady,
Practice to take away from your perfections,
And to preserve your chastity unstain'd,
The most deform'd shape that you can put on
To cloud your bodies faire gifts, or your minds,
(It being laboured to so chaste an end)
Will prove the fairest ornament.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: To take from
The workmanship of Heaven, is an offence
As great, as to endeavour to adde to it;
Of which Ile not be guilty: Chastity
That lodges in deformity, appeares rather
A mulct impos'd by nature, then a blessing;
And tis commendable onely when it conquers,
Though nere so oft assaulted, in resistance:
For me, Ile therefore so dispose my selfe,
That if I hold out, it shall be with honour;
Or if I yeeld, Miranda shall finde something
To make him love his victory. Exit.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: With what cunning
This woman argues for her own damnation?
Nor should I hold it for a miracle,
Since they are all born Sophisters, to maintaine
That lust is lawfull, and the end and use
Of their creation: would I never had
Hop'd better of her; or could not believe,
Though seen the mine, I must ever grieve. Exit.

div.head: Scaena Quarta.
div.stage: Enter Miranda, Norandine, Servants with lights.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Ile see you in your chamber. A Table out tow stools.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Pray ye no farther:
It is a ceremony I expect not,
I am no stranger here, I know my lodging,
And have slept soundly there, when the Turks Cannon
Playd thick upon't: O 'twas Royall Musicke,
And to procure a sound sleep for a Souldier,
Worth forty of your Fiddles. As you love me
Presse it no further.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You will overcome.
Waite on him carefully.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I have tooke since supper
A rouse or two too much, and by—
It warms my blood.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You'l sleep the better for't.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: — on't, I should, had but I a kind wench
To pull my Boot-hose off, and warm my night-cap,
There's no charme like it: I love old Adams way;
Give me a diligent Eve, to wait towards bed-time,
Hang up your smooth chin page: and now I think on't,
Where is your Turkish prisoner?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: In the Castle,
But yet I never saw her.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Fie upon you:
See her for shame? or, hark ye, if you would
Performe the friends part to me, the friends part,
It being a fashion of the last edition,
Far from panderisme, now send her to me;
You look strange on't, no entertainments perfect
Without it on my word; no livery like it;
Ile tell her, he lookes for it as duly
As for his fee; there's no suit got without it,
Gold is an asse to't.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Go to bed, to bed.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Well, if she come, I doubt not to convert her,
If not, the sin lie on your head.
Good night Exit Nor. and Servants.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: There you shall finde hint Lady: you know what I have said,
And if you please you may make use.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No doubt sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: From hence I shall heare all.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Come hither young one.
Beshrew my heart, a handsome wench: come neerer,
A very handsome one: doo not you grieve, Sweet,
You are a prisoner?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The losse of liberty
No doubt sir, is a heavy and sharpe burden
To them that feele it truly: But your servant,
Your humble handmayd, never felt that rigor,
Thanks to that Noble wil: no want, no hunger,
(Companions still to slaves) no violence,
Nor any unbeseeming act, we start at,
Have I yet met with; all content and goodnesse,
Civility, and sweetnesse of behaviour
Dwell round about me; therefore, worthy Master,
I cannot say I grieve my liberty.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Do not you fancie me too cold a Souldier,
Too obstinate an enemy to youth,
That had so faire a Jewell in my Cabinet,
And in so long a time, would nere look on it?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: What can she say now?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sure I desir'd to see ye,
And with a longing wish.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: There's all her vertue.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pursu'd that full desire to give ye thanks sir,
The onely Sacrifice I have left, and service
For all the vertuous care you have kept me safe with.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: She holds well yet.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: The pretty foole, speaks finely:
Come sit down here.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O sir, tis most unseemly.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Ile have it so: fit close; now tell me truly,
Did you ere love yet?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My yeeres will answer that sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And did you then love truly?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: So I thought sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Can ye love me so?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Now!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: With all my duty;
I were unworthy of those favours else,
You daily showre upon me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: What thinkst thou of me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I think ye are a truely worthy Gentleman,
A pattern, and a pride to the age ye live in,
Sweet as the commendations all men give ye.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: A pretty flattering rogue; dare ye kisse that sweet man
Ye speak to sweetly of? Come,

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Farewell vertue.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: What hast thou goe between thy lips? kisse once more.
Sure thou hast a spell there.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: More then ere I knew sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: All hopes goe now.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I must tell you a thing in your eare, and you must heare me,
And heare me willingly, and grant me so too,
Twill not be worth my asking else.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It must be
A very hard thing fir, and from my power,
I shall deny your goodnesse.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Tis a good wench; I must lie with ye Lady.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Tis something strange:
For yet in all my life I knew no bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You will quickly finde that knowledge.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: To what end sir?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Art thou so innocent, thou canst not guesse at it?
Did thy dreams never direct thee?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Faith none yet sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Ile tell thee then: I would meet thy youth and pleasure;
Give thee my youth for that, by Heaven she fires me,
And teach thy faire white armes, like wanton Ives,
A thousand new embraces,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Is that all sir?
And say I should try, may not we lie quietly?
Upon my conscience I could.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: That's as we make it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Grant that, that likes ye best, what would ye doe then?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: What would I do? certainly, I am no baby,
Nor brought up for a Nun; hark in thine eare.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Fie, fie, sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I wold get a brave boy on thee,
A warlike boy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sure we shall get ill Christians.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: We'l mend 'em in the breeding then.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sweet Master.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Never beliefe in woman come neere me more.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My best and noblest sir, if a poor Virgin,
(For yet by— I am so) should change so far
(Seeing your excellence, and able sweetnesse)
To forget her selfe, and slip into your bosome,
Or to your bed, out of a doting on ye,
Take it the best way; have you that cruell heart,
That murdring mind too?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yes by my troth (Sweet) have I,
To lie with her.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And do you think it wel done?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: That's as she'l think when tis done; come to bed wench,
For thou art so pretty, and so witty a companion,
We must not part to night.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Faith let me go sir,
And think better on't.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Y faith thou shalt not;
I warrant thee Ile think on't.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I have heard 'em say here,
You are a mayd too.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I am sure I am, wench,
If that will please thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I have seen a wonder,
And would you lose that for a little wantonnesse,
(Consider my sweet Master, like a man, now,)
For a few honied kisses, sleight embraces,
That glory of your youth, that crown of sweetnesse?
Can ye deliver that unvalued treasure?
Would ye forsake, to seeke your own dishonour,
What gone, no age recovers, nor repentance?
To a poore stranger?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Hold there again, thou art perfect.

sp.speaker: Luc
sp.l: I know you do but try me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And I know
Ile try you a great deale further: prethee to bed;
I love thee, and so well: come kisse me once more;
Is a maidenhead ill bestow'd o' me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What's this sir?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Why, tis the badge (my Sweet) of that holy Order
I shortly must receive, the Crosse of Malta.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What vertue has it?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: All that we call vertuous.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Who gave it first?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: He that gave all, to save us.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Why then tis holy too?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: True sign of holinesse,
The badge of all his Souldiers that professe him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The badge of all his souldiers that professe him,
Can save in dangers?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: In troubles comfort?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You say true, sweet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: In sicknesse, restore health?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: All this it can do.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Preserve from evils, that afflict our frailties.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I hope she will be Christian: all these truly.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Why are you sick then, sick to death with lust?
In danger to be lost? no holy thought,
In all that heart, nothing but wandring frailties
Wild as the wind, and blind as death or ignorance,
Inhabit there.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Forgive me heaven, she sayes true.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Dare ye professe that badg, prophan that goodnes?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Thou hast redeemd thy self again, most rarely.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That holines and truth ye make me wonder at?
Blast all the bounty heaven gives, that remembrance.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: O excellent woman.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Fling it from ye quickly,
If ye be thus resolu'd; I see a vertue
Appear in't like a sword, both edges flaming
That wil consume ye, and your thoughts, to ashes,
Let them professe it that are pure, and noble,
Gentle, and just of thought, that build the crosse,
Not those that break it, by— if ye touch me,
Even in the act, Ile make that crosse, and curse ye.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You shall not (fair) I did dissemble with ye,
And but to try your faith, I fashioned all this:
Yet something you provoakt me: this fair crosse,
By me (if he but please to help, first gave it)
Shall ne'r be worne upon a heart corrupted;
Go to your rest, my modest, honest servant,
My fair, and vertuous maid, and sleep secure there,
For when you suffer, I forget this signe here.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: A man of men too: O most perfect Gentleman!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: All sweet rest to your sir; I am halfe a Christian,
The other half, I'le pray for; then for you, sir;

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: This is the fowlest play I'le shew, good night, sweet.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: The Sun's not set yet?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Would it were,
Never to rise againe to light the world.
And yet, to what vaine purpose do I wish it,
Since though I were inviron'd with thick mists,
Black as Cymerian darknesse, or my crimes,
There is that here, upon which, as an anvile
Ten thousand hammers strike, and every spark
They force from it, to me's an other Sun
To light me to my shame?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Take hope, and comfort.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: They are aides indeed, but yet as far from me,
As I from being innocent: this cave fashioned
By provident nature, in this solid Rock
To be a den for beasts, alone, receives me,
And having prov'd an enemy to mankinde,
All humane helpes forsake me.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: I'le ne'r leave you,
And wish you would call back that noble courage
That old invicible fortitude of yours
That us'd to shrink at nothing.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Then it did not.
But 'twas when I was honest; then in the height
Of all my hapinesse, of all my glories,
Of all delights, that made life pretious to me,
I durst die Rocca; death it self then to me
Was nothing terrible, because I knew,
The fame of a good Knight woulde ever live
Fresh on my memory; but since I fell
From my integrity, and dismis'd those guards,
Those strong assurances of innocence,
That constancy fled from me, and what's worse,
Now I am loathsome to my self; and life
A burthen to me, rackd with sad remembrance
Of what I have done, and my present horrors
Unsufferable to me, torturd with despair
That I shall ne'r find mercy; hell about me,
Behind me, and before me, yet I dare not
Still fearing worse, put off my wretched being. Enter Abdella

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: To see this would deterre a doubtfull man
From mischeivous intents, much more the practise
Of what is wicked: here's the Moore, look up sir,
Some ease may come from her.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: New trouble rather,
And I expect it.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Who is this? Mountferrat?
Rise up for shame, and like a river dride up
With a long drought, from me, your bounteous Sea
Receive those tides of comfort, that flow to you;
If ever I lookt lovely, if desert
Could ever challenge welcom; if revenge,
And unexpected wreak, were ever pleasing
Or could endear the giver of such blessings,
All these I come adorn'd with, and as due
Make challenge of those so long wishd embraces
Which you (unkind) have hitherto denyde me.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Why, what have you done for me?

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Made Gomera
As truly miserable, as you thought him happy,
Could you wish more?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: As if his sicknesse could
Recover me; the injuries I received
Were Orianas.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: She has paid deer for them,
She's dead.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Dead: my hate could reach no further:
Taking advantage of her in a swoon,
Under pretence to give a Cordiall to her
I poysond her: what stupid dulnesse is this?
What you should entertain with sacrifice,
Can you receive so coldly?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Bloody deeds
Are gratefull offrings, pleasing to the devill,
And thou, in thy black shape, and blacker actions
Being hels perfect character, art delighted
To do what I though infinitly wicked,
Tremble to hear: thou hast in this tane from me
All meanes to make amends with penitence,
To her wrongd vertues, and dispoild me of
The poor remainder of that hope was left me,
For all I have already, or must suffer.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: I did it for the best.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: For thy worst ends,
And be assurd, but that, I think to kill thee
Would but prevent, what thy despair must force thee
To do unto thy self, and so to adde to
Thy most assur'd damnation, thou went dead now,
But get thee from my sight: and if lust of me
Did ever fire thee (love, I cannot call it)
Leap down from those steep Rocks, or take advantage
Of the next Tree, to hang thy self, and then
I may laugh at it.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: In the mean time
I must be bold, to do so much for you, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mount,
sp.l: Why grinst thou, devill?

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: That 'tis in my power,
To punish thy ingratiude; I made triall
But how you stood affected, and since I know
I am us'd only for a property,
I can, and will revenge it to the full.
For, understand, in thy contempt of me
Those hopes of Oriana, which I could
Have changd to certainties, are lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Why, lives she?

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Yes, but never to Mountferrat,
Although it is in me, with as much ease
To give her freely up to thy possession,
As to remove this rush, which yet despaire of,
For by my much wrongd love, flattery, nor threats,
Teares, prayers, nor vowes, shall ever win me to it:
So with my curse, I leave thee.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Prethee stay,
Thou knowst' I doat on thee, and yet thou art
So peevish, and perverse, so apt to take
Triffles unkindly from me.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: To perswade me
To break my neck, to hang, then damn my self,
With you are trifles.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: 'T was my melancholy
That made me speak I know not what: forgive,
I will redeem my fault.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Believe him Lady.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: A thousand times I will demand thy pardon,
And keep the reckoning on thy lips, with kisses.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Ther's something els, that would prevaile more with me.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Thou shalt have all thy wishes do but blesse me
With meanes to satisfie my madde desires
For once in Oriana, and for ever
I am thine, only thine my best Abdella.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Were I assur'd of this, and that you would
Having enioyd her.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Any thing: make choice of
Thine own conditions.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Swear then, that performed.
(To free me from all doubts and fears hereafter)
To give me leave to kill her.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: That our safety
Must of necessity urge us to.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Then know
It was not poyson, but a sleeping potion
Which she received, yet of sufficient strength
So to bind up her sences, that no signe
Of life appeard in her, and thus thought dead
In her best habit, as the custome is
You know in Malta, with all ceremonies
She's buried in her families monument,
In the Temple of St. Iohn; I'le bring you thither,
Thus, as you are disguisd; some six howers hence
The potion will leave working.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Let us haste then. Discover Tombe

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Be my good angel, guid me.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: But remember
You keep your Oath.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: As I desire to prosper
In what I undertake.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: I ask no more. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Here sir, I have got the Key, I borrowd it
Of him that keeps the Church, the door is open.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Look to the horses then, and please the fellow.
After a few devotions, I'le retire.
Be not far off, there may be some use of ye,
Give me the light: come friend, a few good prayers
Were not bestowd in vaine now, even from you sir.
Men that are bred in blood, have no way left 'em,
No bath, no purge, no time to weare it out
Or wash it off, but penitence, and prayer:
I am to take the order, and my youth
Loaden I must confesse with many follies,
Circled and bound about with sins as many
As in the house of memory live figures.
My heart I'le open now, my faults confesse.
And rise a new man, heaven I hope, to a new life.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I have no great devotion, at this instant,
But for a prayer or two, I will not out sir,
Hold up your finger, when you have praid enough.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Go you to that end.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I shall ne'r pray alone sure,
sp.p: I have bin so us'd to answer the Clerk: would I had a cushion, for I shall ne'r make a good Hermit, and knee till my knees are horn, these stones are plaguy hard where shal I begin now? for if I do not observe a method, I shall be out presently.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: What's that sir? did ye heare?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Ha; to your prayers.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: 'Twas here abouts, t'has put me clean awry now,
I shall ne'r get in again, ha, by Land,
And water, all children, and all women,
I there it was I left.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Never tell me sir,
Here's something got amongst us.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I heard a groane:
A dismall one,— Ori. Oh, Oh.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Here, tis here sir, 'tis here sir;
A devill in the wall.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Tis some illusion
To fright us from devotion— Ori. Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Why tis here,
The spirit of a huntesman choakd with butter,
Her's a new tomb, new trickments too.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: For certaine,
This has not bin three dayes here.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: And a Tablet
With rimes upon't.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I prethee read 'em Norandine.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: An Epi— and Epi— taff. I think 'tis, I 'tis taff, an Epitaff.
Upon the most excell, excell— lent— and.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Thou canst not read.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I have spoild mine eyes with gunpowder,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: An Epitaph upon the most vertuous, and excellent Lady
The honor of Chastity, Oriana.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: The grand masters sister: how a devil came she here?
When slipt she out oth' way, the stone's but half upon her.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Tis is a sodain chang: certain the mischiefe
Mountferrat offerd to her broak her heart-strings.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Would he were here, I would be the clerk my self,
And by this little light. I would bury him alive here,
Her's no lamenting now.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: There tis.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sure from the monument, the very stone groanes for her.
Oh, deer Lady: blessing of women, vertue of thy sex;
How art thou set for ever, how stolne from us.
Babling, and prating now converse with women.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Sir it rises, it looks up. She rises up.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Heaven blesse us.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: It is in womans cloathes, it rises higher.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: It looks about, and wonders, sure she lives sir.
Tis she, tis Oriana, tis that Lady.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Shall I go to her?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Where am I!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Stand still.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: What place is this?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: She is as live as I am.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: What sinell of earth, and rotten bones, what dark place.
Lord, whether am I carried?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: How she stares,
And sets her eyes upon him.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How is't deer Lady?
Do you know me, how she shakes?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: You are a man.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: A man that honours you.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: A cruell man,
Ye are all cruell: are you in your grave too?
For ther's no trusting cruell man, above ground.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: byr' Lady, that goes hard.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: To do your service
And to restore ye to the joyes you were in.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: I was in joyes indeed, and hope—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: She sincks againe
Again she is gon; she is gon: gon as a shadow,
She sinks for ever, friend.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: She is cold now,
She is certainly departed, I must cry too.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: The blessed angels guide thee: put the stone too,
Beauty thou art gon to dust, goodnesse to ashes.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Pray take it well: we must all have our houres sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I, thus we are; and all our painted glory,
A buble that a boy blowes in toth' ayre,
And there it breaks.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I am glad ye sav'd her honour yet.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Would I had sav'd her life now too: oh heaven
For such a blessing, such a timely blessing
O friend, what deer content 't would be, what story
To keep my name from wormes?

sp.speaker: Oria
sp.l: Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: She lives again,
'Twas but a trance.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Pray ye call my man in presently
Help with the stone first, oh she stirs againe.
Oh call my man away.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I fly, I fly sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Upon my knees O heaven, O heaven I thank thee. The living heat steales into every member; En. Colonn. & Come help the Coffin out, softly, and sodainly Norand. Where is the Clerk?.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Drunk above, he is sure sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sirah, you must be secret.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: As your soule sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Softly good friend, take her into your armes.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Put in the crust againe.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And bring her out there when I am a horseback
My man, and I will tenderly conduct her
Unto the Fort; slay you, and watch what issue,
And what inquirie's for the body.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Well sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And when ye have done, come back to me.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Softly, oh softly.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: She growes warmer still sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: What shall I do with 'Key?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Thou canst not stir now,
Leave it ith' door: go get the horses ready. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: The door's already open, the Key in it. En. Rocca Mountferrat Abdella. With a dark lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: What were those past by?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Some scout of Souldiers, I think.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: It may be well so, for I saw their horses,
They saw not us I hope.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: No, no, we were close,
Beside they were far off.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: What time of night is't?

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Much about twelve I think.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Let me go in first
For by the leaving open of the door here
There may be some body in the Church: give me the Lanthorne.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: You'l love me now I hope.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Make that good to me
Your promise is engaged for.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Why she is there
Ready prepar'd, and much about this time
Life will look up again.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Come in all's sure,
Not a foot stirring, nor a tongue.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Heaven blesse me,
I never enter'd with such unholy thoughts
This place before.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Ye are a fearfull foole,
If men have appetites allow'd 'em,
And warm desires, are there not ends too for 'em?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Whether shall we carry her?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Why, to the bark, sir,
I have provided one already waites us
The wind stands wondtrous fair too for our passge.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: And there, when ye'have enjoyd her, for ye have that liberty
Let me alone to send her to feed fishes,
I'le no more sighes for her.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Where is the monument?
Thou art sure she will awake about this time?

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Most sure, If she be not knockt oth' head: give me the Lanthorn,
Here 'tis, how is this, the stone off?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: I, and nothing
Within the monument, that's worse, no body
I am sure of that, nor signe of any here,
But an empty Coffin.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: No Lady.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: No, nor Lord sir,
This Pye has bin cut up before.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Either the Devill
Must doe these tricks—

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Or thou, damn'd one, worse;
Thou black swoln pitchie cloud, of all my afflictions:
Thou night hag, gotten when the bright Moone sufferd
Thou hell it self confin'd in flesh: what trick now?
Tell me, and tell me quickly what thy mischief
Has done with her, and to what end, and whether
Thou hast remov'd her body, or by this holy place
This sword shall cut thee into thousand peeces.
A thousand thousand, strow thee ore the Temple
A sacrifice to thy black sire, the Devill.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Tell him, you see he's angry.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Let him burst,
Neither his sword, nor anger do I shake at,
Nor will yeild to feed his poor suspitions,
His idle jealouzies, and madde dogs heares
One thought against my self: ye have done a brave deed
A manly, and a valiant peece of Service
When ye have kill'd me; reckon't amongst your Battels:
I am sorry ye are so poore, so weake a gentleman
Able to stand no fortune: I dispose of her?
My mischiefe make her away? a likely project,
I must play booty against my selfe, if any thing crosse ye
I am the devill, and the devils heire,
All plagues, all mischiefes.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Will I ye leave and doe yet?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: I have done too much,
For, far too much for such a thanklesse fellow,
If I be devill, you created me,
I never knew those arts, nor bloody practises
(— o' your cunning heart, that mine of mischiefe)
Before your flatteries won 'em into me,
Here did I leave her, leave her with that certainty
About this houre to wake again.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Where is she?
This is the last demand.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Did I now know it,
And were I sure, this were my latest minute
I would not tell thee: strike, and then I'le curse thee:

sp.speaker: Rocca
sp.l: I see a light, stand close, and leave your angers.
We all miscarry else. Enter Gomera, Page with Torch.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: I am now carelesse,

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Peace, prethee peace, sweet, peace, all friends,

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Stand close then.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Waite there Boy, with the light, till I call to thee,
In darknesse was my soule and sences clouded
When my faire Jewell fell, the night of jealousie,
In all her blacknesse drawn about my judgement:
No light was let into me: to distinguish
Betwixt my suddain anger and her honour,
A blinde sad Pilgrimage shall be my pennance,
No comfort of the day will I looke up at:
Far darker then my jealous Ignorance
Each place of my aboad shall do my: prayers
No ceremonious lights shall set off more;
Bright Armes, and all that carry lustre, life,
Society, and sollace, I forsake ye.
And were it not once more to see her beauties
(For in her bed of death, she must be sweet still,)
And on her cold sad lips seal my repentance;
Thou child of heaven, faire light I could not misse thee.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: I know the tongue, would I were out againe I have done him too much wrong to looke upon him.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: There is no shifting now, boldnesse, and confidence
Must carry it now away: he is but one neither,
Naked as you are, of a strength far under

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: But he has a cause above me,

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: That's as you handle it.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Peace: he may goe againe, and never see us.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: I feele I weepe apace, but where's the flood,
The torrent of my teares, to drown my fault in,
I would I could now like a loaden cloud
Begotten in the moyst south, drop to nothing
Give me the Torch, Boy.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Now he must discover us.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: He has already, never hide your head
Be bold, and brave, if we must dye together.

sp.speaker: Gom:
sp.l: Who's there? what friend to sorrow? The Tombe wide open
The Stone off too? the body gone, by—
Looke to the doore Boy: keep it fast, who are ye?
What sacrilegious villaines? false Mountferrat,
The wolfe to honour, has thy hellish hunger,
Brought thee to tear the body out oth' tomb too?
Has thy foule mind so far wrought on thee? ha,
Are you there too? nay, then I spie a villany
I never dream't of yet, thou sinfull usher
Bred from that rottennesse, thou bawd to mischiefe,
Doe you blush through all your blacknesse? will not that hide it?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: I cannot speake.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: You are well met, with your dam, sir,
Art thou a Knight? did ever on that sword,
The Christian cause sit nobly? could that hand fight,
Guided by fame, and fortune? that heart inflame thee,
With vertuous fires of valour, to fall off,
Fall off so suddainly, and with such foulenesse,
As the false Angels did, from all their glory?
Thou art no Knight, honour thou never heard'st of,
Nor brave desires could ever build in that breast,
Treason, and tainted thoughts, are all the Gods
Thou worship'st, all the strength thou hadst: and fortune;
Thou didst things out of feare, and false heart, villaine
Out of close traps and treacheries, they have rais'd thee.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Thon rav'st old man.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Before thou get'st off from me,
Had'st thou the glory of thy first fights on thee
Which thou hast basely lost, thy noblest fortunes,
And in their greatest lustres, I would make thee
Before we part, confesse, nay, kneele, and doe it,
Nay, crying kneele, coldly for mercy, crying:
Thou art the recreant'st Rogue, time ever nourish'd,
Thou art a dogge, I will make thee sweare, a dog stav'd,
A mangy Cur-dogge; doe you creep behind the Altar?
Looke how it sweats, to shelter such a rascall;
First, with thy venemous tooth infect her chaste life,
And then not dare to doe; next, rob her rest,
Steale her dead body out oth' grave.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I have not.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: Prethee come out, this is no place to quarrell in, Valiant Mountferrat come,

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I will not stir.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Thou hast thy sword about thee,
That good sword, that never fail'd thee: prethee come,
We'l have but five stroakes for it, on, on Boy,
Here's one would faine be acquainted with thee,
Would wondrous fain cleave that Calves-head of yours sir,
Come, prethee let's dispatch, the Moone shines finely:
Prethee be kill'd by me, thou wilt be hang'd else,
But it may be, thou long'st to be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Out with him, Sir,
You shall have my sword too: when he's dispatch'd once
We have the world before us.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Wilt thou walke fellow,
I never knew a Rogue, hang arse-ward so,
And such a desperate knave too.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Pray goe with him,
Something I'le promise too,

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: You would be kill'd then?
No remedy; I see,

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: If thou dar'st doe it?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Yes, now I dare; lead out, I'le follow presently Vnder the Mount I'le meet ye.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Goe before me,
He have ye in a string too.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: As I am a Gentleman,
And by this holy place, I will not faile thee,
Feare not, thou shalt be kill'd, take my word for it
I will not faile.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: If thou seap'st thou hast Cats luck,
The Mount?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: The same: make haste, I am there before else.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Goe get ye home; now if he scape I am Cowar'd.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Well, now I am resolv'd, and he shall finde it.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How is it with the Lady?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sir, as well
As it can be with one, who feeling knowes now
What is the curse the divine justice lay'd
On the first sinfull woman.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Is she in travell?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Yes sir; and yet the troubles of her mind
Afflict her more, then what her body suffers,
For in the extremity of her paine, she cries out,
Why am I here? Where is my Lord Gomera,
Then sometimes names Miranda, and then sighes,
As if to speake, what questionlesse she loves well,
If heard, might doe her injury.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Heavens sweet mercy
Looke gently on her,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Prethee tell her, my Prayers
Are present with her, and good wench provide
That she want nothing: what's thy name?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Lucinda.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Lucinda? there's a prosperous omen in it,
Bea Lucina to her, and bring word
That she is safe delivered of her burthen,
And thy rewards thy liberty: come Collonna,
We will goe see how th' Engineer has mounted
The Canon the great Master sent, be carefull.
To view the workes, and learn the discipline
That is us'd here: I am to leave the world
And for your service, which I have found faithfull.
The charge that's mine, if I have any power
Hereafter may concerne you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I still finde
A noble Master in you,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Tis but justice,
sp.p: Thou do'st deserve it in thy care, and duty. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Gomera, Mountferrat, Rocca, Abdella, with a Pistoll.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: Here's even ground, I'le stir no foot beyond it, Before I have thy head.

sp.speaker: Maunt.
sp.l: Draw Rocca.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Coward,
Hath inward guilt, rob'd thee as well of courage
As honesty? that without oddes thou dar'st not
Answer a single Enemy?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: All advantage
That I can take, expect.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: We know you are valiant,
Nor doe we purpose to make further triall
Of what you can doe now: but to dispatch you.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: And therefore fight, and pray together.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Villaines,
Whose basenesse, all disgracefull words made one,
Cannot expresse; so strong is the good cause
That seconds me, that you shall feele, with horrour
To your proud hopes, what strength is in that arme,
Though old, that holds a sword made sharp by justice.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: You come then here, to prate? fight.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Helpe Rocca, now,
Or I am lost forever; how comes this?
Are villany, and weaknesse twynes?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: I am gone too.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: You shall not scape me, wretches,

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: I must doe it,
All will goe wrong else. shoots him

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Treacherous bloody woman,
What hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Done a poor womans part,
And in an instant, what these men so long
Stood fooling for.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: This aide was unexpected,
I kisse thee for't,

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: His right armes onely shot,
And that compell'd him to forsake his sword,
He's else unwounded.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Forbeare.
Yet doe not hope 'tis with intent to save thee.
But that thou maist live to thy farther torment
To see who triumphes over thee: come Mountferrat,
Here joyne thy foot to mine, and let our hearts
Meet with our hands, the contract that is made
And cemented with blood, as this of ours is,
Is a more holy sanction, and much surer,
Then all the superstitious ceremonies Enter Norandine.
You Christians use.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Who's this?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Betray'd againe?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: By the report it made, and by the wind
The Pistoll was discharged here.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Norandine,
As ever thou lov'st valour, or wear'st Armes
To punish basenesse, shew it.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: O the devill,
Gomera wounded, and my Brache black beauty
An actor in it?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: If thou strik'st, I'le shoot thee.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: How? fright me with your Pot-gun? what art thou?
Good heaven, the Rogue, the traytor rogue Mountferrat
To swinge the neast of you, is a sport unlook'd for,
Hels— consume you.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: As thou art a man;
I am wounded, give me time to answer thee.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Durst thou urge this? this hand can hold a sword yet.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Well done: to see this villaine, makes my hurts
Bleed fresh againe, but had I not a bone whole,
In such a cause I should doe thus, thus Rascals. Enter Corporall and watch.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Disarme them, and shoot any that resists.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Hold Corporall; I am Gomera,

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Tis well yet, that once in an age you can
Remember what you watch for; I had thought
You had again been making out your parties
For sucking piggs.
'Tis well:

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: As you will answer
The contrary with your lives, see these forth coming.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: That we shall doe.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: You bleed a pace: good Souldiers
Goe helpe him to a Surgeon,

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Dare the worst,
And susser like your selfe.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: From me learne courage.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Now for Miranda, this newes will be to him
As welcome, as 'tis unexpected: Corporall,
There's something for thy care to night: my horse there.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: How do's my Boy?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Oh, wondrous lusty, Madam,
A little Knight already: you shall live
To see him tosse a Turke.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Gentle Lucinda,
Much must I thank thee for thy care, and service.
And may I grow but strong to see Valetta, Enter Miranda, Norandine, Collonna.
My husband, and my brother, thou shalt finde
I will not barely thank thee.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Looke Captaine, we must ride away this morning
The Auberge sits to day, and the great Master
Writes plainly, I must or deliver in
(The yeere expir'd) my probation weed,
Or take the Cloake: you likewise Norandine
For your full service, and your last assistance
In false Mountferrats apprehension
Are here commanded to associate me; my twin in this high honour.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: Ile none on't: doe they think to bind me to live chaste, sober, and temperately, all dayes of my life? they may as soone tye an Englishman to live so: I shall be a sweet Dane, a sweet Captaine, goe up and downe drinking small beere, and swearing odds neagues; no Ile live a Squire at Armes still, and doe thou so too; and thou beest wise: I have found the mystery now, why the Gentlemen weare but three barres of the crosse, and the knights the whole one.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Why Captaine?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: Mary sir, to put us in remembrance, we are but three quarters cross'd in our licence, and pleasures: but the poore Knights cross'd altogther; the brothers at Armes, may yet meet with their Sisters at Armes, now and then, in brotherly love; but the poore Knights cannot get a Lady for love, nor money: 'tis not so in other Countries I wis, pray haste you, for I'le along, and see what will come on't. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Collonna, provide strait, all necessaries
For this remove, the Lytter for the Lady,
And let Lucinda beare her company,
You shall attend on me.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.l: With all my duties Exit.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How fare you, gracious Mistresse?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: O Miranda.
You pleas'd to honour me with that faire title
When I was free, and could dispose my selfe;
But now, no smile, no word, no looke, no touch
Can I impart to any, but as theft
From my Gomera; and who dares accept,
Is an usurper.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Leave us; I have touch'd thee,
(Thou fairer vertue, then thou'rt beautifull)
Hold but this test, so rich an one was never Altar ready, Tapers & booke
Try'd by the hand of man, on the vast earth:
Sit brightest Oriana, is it sinne
Still to professe I love you, still to vow
I shall doe ever? heaven my witnesse be,
'Tis not your eye, your cheeke, your tongue, no part
That superficially doth snare young men,
Which has caught me; read over in your thoughts
The story that this man hath made of you,
And thinke upon his merit.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Onely thought
Can comprehend it.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And can you be so
Cruell, thankelesse, to destroy his youth
That sav'd your honour, gave you double life?
Your own, and your faire Infants? that when fortune
(The blind foe to all beauty, that is good,)
Bandied you from one hazard to another,
Was even heavens Messenger, by providence
Call'd to the Temple, to receive you there,
Into these Armes, to give ease to your throwes,
As if't had thunder'd; take thy due Miranda,
For she was thine; Gomera's jealousie
Strooke death unto thy heart; to him be dead,
And live to me, that gave thee second life:
Let me but now enjoy thee: Oh regard
The torturing fires of my affections.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Oh master them, Miranda, as I mine;
Who follows his desires, such tyrants serves
As will oppresse him, insupportably.
My flames, Miranda, rise as high as thine,
For I did love thee 'fore my marriage,
Yet would I now consent, or could I think
Thou wert in earnest, (which by all the soules
That have (for chastity) been sanctified
I cannot) in a moment I doe know
thou'ldst call faire temperance up to rule thy blood,
Thy eye was ever chaste, thy countenance too honest,
And all thy woings was like maidens talk;
Who yeeldeth unto pleasures, and to lust
Is a poore captive, that in Golden Fetters
(And pretious (as he thinkes) but holding gyves)
Frets out his life.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Find such another woman,
And take her for his labour, any man:

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: I was not worthy of thee, at my best,
Heaven knew I was not, I had had thee else;
Much lesse now gentle sir; Mirandas deeds
Have been as white, as Orianas fame,
From the beginning, to this point of time,
And shall we now begin to staine both thus?
Think on the legend which we two shall breed
Continuing as we are, for chastest dames
And boldest Souldiers to peruse and read,
I and read thorough, free from any act
To cause the modest cast the booke away,
And the most honour'd Captaine fold it up.

sp.speaker: Mir;
sp.l: Fairest; let goe my hand: my pulse beats thick,
And my mov'd blood rides high in every vaine,
Lord of thy selfe now, Souldier, and ever:
I would not for Aleppo, this fraile Bark,
This barke of flesh, no better fleeres-man had
Then has Mountferrat's: may you kisse me, Lady?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: No; though't be no essentiall injury,
It is a circumstance due to my Lord,
To none else: and my deerest friend, if hands
Playing together, kindle heate in you,
What may the game at lips provoke unto?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Oh what a tongue is here? whil'st she doth teach
My heart to hate my fond unlawfull love,
She talkes me more in love, with love to her,
My fires she quencheth with her arguments,
But as she breathes 'em, they blow fresher fires.
Sir further: now my flame cooles; husband, wife,
There is some holy mystery in those names
That sure the unmarried cannot understand.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Now thou art strait, and do'st enamour me,
So far beyhind a carnall earthly love;
My very soule doats on thee, and my spirits
Doe embrace thine, my minde doth thy mind kisse,
And in this pure conjunction we enjoy
A heavenlyer pleasure then if bodies met:
This, this is perfect love, the other short,
Yet languishing fruition, every Swaine
And sweating Groome may clasp, but our's refinde
Two in ten ages cannot reach unto;
Nor is our spirituall love, a barren joy,
For mark what blessed issue we'll beget,
Deerer then children to posterity,
A great example to mens continence,
And womens chastity, that is a childe
More faire, and comfortable, then any heire.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: If all wives were but such, lust would not finde
One corner to inhabit, sinne would be
So strange, remission superfluous:
But one petition, I have done.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: What (Sweet?).

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: To call me Lord, if the hard hand of death seize on Gomera first.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Oh, much too worthy;
How much you undervalue your own price,
To give your unbought selfe, for a poore woman,
That has been once sold, us'd, and lost her show?
I am a garment worne, a vessell crack'd,
A zoane untide, a Lilly trod upon,
A fragrant flowre cropt by anothers hand,
My colour sullyde, and my odour chang'd,
If when I was new blossom'd, I did feare
My selfe unworthy of Mirandas spring:
Thus over-blown, and seeded, I am rather
Fit to adorn his Chimney, then his bed.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Rise miracle: save Malta, with thy vertue,
If words could make me proud, how has she spoke,
Yet I will try her to the very block:
Hard-hearted, and uncivill Oriana,
Ingratefull payer of my industries,
That with a soft painted hypocrisie
Cozen'st, and geer'st my perturbation,
Expect a witty, and a fell revenge:
My comfort is, all men will thinke thee false,
Beside thy husband having been thus long Enter Nor. Collonna & Lucinda with a Childe.
(on this occasion) in my Fort, and power.
Ile heare no more words: Captaine, let's away
With all care see to her: and you Lucinda
Attend her diligently: she is a wonder.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Have you found she was well delivered:
What, had she a good Mid-wife, is all well?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You are merry Norandine.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Why weepe you, Lady?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Take the poor Babe along.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Madam 'tis here.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Dissembling death, why didst thou let me live
To see this change, my greatest cause to grieve? Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena secunda.
div.stage: Enter Astorius, Castriot, Valetta, Gomera, Synnet: Knights, 2 Bishops, Mountferrat, guarded by Corporall and Souldiers, Abdella, a Gentleman with a cloake, sword, and Spurres: Gomara.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A tender husband hast thou shew'd thy selfe
My deerest brother, and thy memory
After my life, in brazen Characters,
Shall monumentally be register'd
To ages consequent, till times running hand,
Beats back the world to undistinguish'd Chaos,
And on the top of that thy name shall stand
Fresh, and without decay.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Oh honour'd sir!
If hope of this, or any blisse to come
Could lift my load of griefe off from my soule,
Or expiate the trespasse 'gainst my wife,
That in one houres suspition I begat,
I might be won to be a man againe,
And fare like other husbands, sleepe and eate,
Laugh, and forget my pleasing penitence;
But till old nature can make such a wife
Againe, I vow ne're to resume the order
And habits, that to men are necessary,
All breath I'le spend in sighes, all sound in groanes,
And know no company but my wasting moans.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: This will be wilfull murder on your self,
Nor like a Christian doe you beare the chance
Which th'inscrutable will of heaven admits.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: What would you have my weaknesse doe, that
Suffer'd it selfe thus to be practis'd on,
By a damn'd hell-hound, and his agent dam,
The impious mid-wife to obortive birthes,
And cruell instrument to his decrees?
By forgery they first assail'd her life,
Heaven playing with us yet, in that, he wrought
My deerest friend, the servant to her vertue
To combat me, against his Mistresse truth.
That yet effectlesse, this enchanting witch,
Bred banefull jealousie against my Lady,
My most immaculate Lady, which seiz'd on her
Almost to death: Oh yet! not yet content,
She in my hand put (to restore her life
As I imagin'd) what did execute
Their devillish malice, farther, great with childe,
Was this poore innocent, that too was lost,
They doubled death upon her, not staying there,
They have done violence unto her Tomb,
Not granting rest unto her in the grave:
I wish Miranda had injoy'd my prize;
For sure I'm punish'd for usurping her,
Oh what a Tyger is resisted Lust?
How it doth forrage all?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Part of this tale
I grant you true; but 'twas not poyson given her.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: I would it had, we had been farre enough,
If we had been so wise, and had not now
Stood curtsing for your mercies here.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Beside,
What is become oth' body? we know not.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Peace impudents,
And deere Gomera practise patience
As I my self must, by some meanes at last
We shall dissolve this riddle.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Wherefore comes
This villaine in the festivall array,
As if he triumph'd for his treacherie?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: That is by our appointment: give us leave,
You shall know why a non. Enter Miranda, Norandine, Collona.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: One of the Esguard.

sp.speaker: Esg.
sp.l: The Gentlemen are come,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Truyce then a while
With our sad thoughts; what are you both resolv'd?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Not I my Lord: your downe right Captain still
Ile live, and serve you, not that altogether
I want compunction of conscience,
I have enough to save me, and that's all,
Bar me from drink, and drabs, ev'n hang me too,
You must ev'n make your Captaines capons first,
I have too much flesh for this spirituall Knighthood,
And therefore do desire forbearance, sir,
Till I am older, or more mortifide,
I am too sound yet.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What say you Miranda?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: With all pure zeale to Heaven, duty to you,
I come to undergo it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Proceed toth' ceremony.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Before you match with this bright honor'd title,
Admir'd Miranda, pardon what in thought
I ever did transgresse against your vertue,
And may you find more joy with your new bride
Then poor Gomera ere in joyd with his.
But 'twas mine own crime, and I suffer for't:
Long wear your dignity, and worthily,
Whilst I obscurely in some corner vanish,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Have stronger thoughts, and better, first I crave
According to the order of the Court
I may dispose my captives, and the fort,
That with a clean and purified heart
The fittiler I may endue my roabe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Tis granted. Enter Oriana vaild, Ladies, Lucinda, child.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Bring the captives. To your charge
And staid tuition my most noble friend;
I then commend this Lady; start not off
A fairer, and a chaster never liv'd;
By her own choyce you are her Guardian,
For telling her I was to leave my fort,
And to abandon quite all worldly cares.
Her own request was, to Gomeras hands
She might be given in custody, for sh'ad heard
He was a Gentleman wise, and temperate,
Full of humanity to womenkind,
And cause he had bin married knew the better
How to entreat a Lady.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What Country woman is she?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Borne a Greek.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Gomera, 'twill be barbarous to deny
A Lady, that unto your refuge flyes,
And seekes to shrowd her under vertues wing.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Excuse me noble sir; oh think me not
So dull a devill, to forget the losse
Of such a matchlesse wife as I posses'd,
And ever to endure the sight of woman:
Were she the abstract of her sex for forme,
The only warehouse of perfection,
Where there no Rose, nor Lilly but her Cheek,
No Musick but her tongue; vertue but hers;
She must not rest near me, my vow is graven,
Here in my heart, irrevocably breath'd
And when I break it,

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: This is rudenesse Spaniard,
Unseasonably you play the Timonist,
Put on a disposition is not yours,
Which neither fits you, nor becomes you.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: We cannot force you but we would perswade.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Beseech you Sir, no more I am resolv'd
To forsake Malta, tread a Pilgrimage
To faire Jerusalem, for my Ladies soule,
And will not be diverted.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You must beare
This Child along 'we then.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: What Child?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Nay then Gomera, thou art injurious,
This child is thine, and this rejected Lady
Thou hast as often known, as thine own wife,
And this I'le make good on thee, with my sword.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Thou durst as well blaspheme: if such a scandall
(I crave the rights due to a Gentleman)
Women unvaile.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Will you refuse me yet?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: My wife!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My sister!

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Some body, thank Heaven
I cannot speak.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: All praise be ever given:

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: This saves our lives, yet would she had bin dead;
The very sight of her afflicts me more
Then fear of punishment, or my disgrace.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How came you to the Temple?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sir, to do
My poor devotions, and to offer thanks
For scaping a temptation ne'r perform'd
With this faire virgin. I restore a wife
Earth cannot paralell: and busie nature
If thou wilt still make women, but remember
To work 'em by this sampler; take heed sir,
Henceforth you never doubt sir.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: When I do
Death take me sodainly.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: To encrease your happinesse
To your best wife, take this addition.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Alack, my poor knave.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The confession
The Moor made 't seemes was truth.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: Mary was it sir; the only truth that ever issud out of hell, which her black jawes resemble; a plague o' your bacon-face, you must be giving drinks with a vengance; ah thou branded bitch: do'ye stare, gogles, I hope to make winter bootes o' thy hide yet, she feares not damning: hell fire cannot parch her blacker then she is: do'ye grin, chimney sweeper.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: What is't Miranda?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: That you would please Lucinda might attend you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: That suit sir, I consent not to.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My husband?
My deerest Angelo?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: More liggam bobs; is not this the fellow that swom
Like a duck to th'shoare in our sea-service?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: The very same, do not you know me now sir,
My name is Angelo, though Colonna vaild it,
Your Countryman, and kinsman born in Florence,
Who from the neighbour Island here of Goza
Whas captive lead, in that unfortunate day
When the Turk bore with him three thousand soules;
Since in Constantinople have I liv'd
Where I beheld this Turkish Damosell first.
A tedious suitor was I for her love,
And pittying such a beauteous case should hide
A soule prophan'd with infidelity,
I labourd her conversion with my love,
And doubly won her, to faire faith her soule
She first betroth'd, and then her faith to me,
But fearfull there to consummate this contract
We fled, and in that flight were tane againe
By those same Gallies, fore Valletta fought.
Since in your service I attended her,
Where, what I saw, and heard, hath joy'd me more
Then all my past afflictions greiv'd before.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Wonders crown wonders: take thy wife Miranda.
Be henceforth called our Malta's better angell,
And thou her evill Mountferrat.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: Wee'l call him Cacodemon, with his block gib there, his Succuba, his devils seed, his spawn of Phlegeton, that o' my conscience was bred o' the spume of Cocitus; do ye snarle you black jill? she looks lie the Picture of America.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why stay we now.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: This last petition to the Court,
I may bequeath the keeping of my Fort
To this my kinsman, toward the maintenance
Of him, and his faire vertuous wife; discreet,
Loyall, and valiant I dare give him you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You must not ask in vaine, sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: My best thanks
To you my noble Cozen, and my service
To the whole Court; may I deserve this bounty.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Proceed to th'ceremony, one of our Esguard
Degrade Mountferrat first

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I will not sue
For mercy, 'twere in vaine; fortune thy worst. Musick

div.stage: An altar discovered, with Tapers, and a book on it. The two Bishops stand on each side of it Mountferrat as the Song is singing ascends up the altar.

sp.l: See see, the staine of honor, vertues foe,
Of Virgins fair fames, the foule overthrow,
That broken hath his oath of chastity
Dishonor'd much this holy dignity,
Off with his Roab, expell him forth this place,
Whilst we rejoyce, and sing at his disgrace.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Since by thy actions thou hast made thy self
Unworthy of that worthy signe thou wearest,
And of our sacred order, into which
For former vertues, we receiv'd thee first,
According to our Statutes, Ordinances,
For praise unto the good, a terror to
The bad, and an example to all men;
We here deprive thee of our habit, and
Declare thee unworthy our society,
From which we do expell thee, as a rotten
Corrupted, and contagious member.

sp.speaker: Esq.
sp.l: Using th'authority th'Superiour
Hath given unto me, I unty this knot,
And take from thee the pleasing yoak of heaven:
We take from off thy breast this holy crosse,
Which thou hast made thy burthen, not thy prop;
Thy spurs we spoile thee off, eleaving thy heeles
Bare of thy honour, that have kick'd against
Our orders precepts: next we reave thy sword,
And give thee armelesse to thy enemies,
For being foe to goodnesse, and to God,
Last, 'bout thy stiff neck, we this halter hang,
And leave thee to the mercy of the Court.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Invest Miranda.
Faire child of vertue, honors bloome
That here with burning zeale dost come
With joy to ask the white crosse cloak,
And yeild unto this pleasing yoake
That being yong, vowes chastity,
And choosest wilfull poverty;
As this flame mounts, so mount thy zeale, thy glory
Rise past the Stars, and fix in Heaven thy story.

sp.speaker: 1. Bish.
sp.l: What crave you gentle sir?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Humble admittance
To be a brother of the holy Hospitall
Of great Jerusalem.

sp.speaker: 2. Bish.
sp.l: Breath out your vow.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: To heaven and all the bench of Saints above
Whose succour I implore t'enhable me,
I vow henceforth a chaste life, not to enjoy
Any thing proper to my self; obedience
To my superiours, whom Religion,
And Heaven shall give me: ever to defend
The vertuous fame of Ladies, and to oppugne
Even unto death the Christian enemy,
This do I vow to accomplish.

sp.speaker: Esq.
sp.l: Who can tell,
H'as he made other vow, or promis'd marriage
To any one, or is in servitude?

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: He's free from all these.

sp.speaker: 1. Bish.
sp.l: Put on his spurs, and girt him with the sword,
The scourge of infidels, and tipes of speed.
Buildst thy faith on this

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: On him that di'd
On such a sacred figure, for our sins.

sp.speaker: 2. Bish.
sp.l: Here, then we fix it on thy left side, for
Thy encrease of faith, Christian defence, and service
To th'poor, and thus near to thy heart we plant it
That thou maist love it even with all thy heart,
With thy right hand protect, preserve it whole,
For if thou fighting 'gainst heavens enemies
Shall fly away, abandoning the crosse
The Ensigne of thy holy Generall,
With shame thou justly shalt be rob'd of it
Chas'd from our company, and cut away
As an infectious putrified limb.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I aske no favour.

sp.speaker: 1 Bish.
sp.l: Then receive the yoak
Of him that makes it sweet, and light, in which
Thy soule find her eternall rest.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Most welcome.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Welcome, our noble brother.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Break up the Court; Mountferrat, though your deeds
Conspiring 'gainst the lives of innocents
Hath forfeited your own, we will not staine
Our white Crosse with your blood: your doom is then
To marry this coagent of your mischiefes
Which done, we banish you the continent,
If either, after three dayes here be found
The hand of Law, layes hold upon your lives.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: Away French stallion, now you have a Barbary mare of your own, go leap her, and engender young devillings.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We will find something, noble Norandine
To quit your merit: so to civill feasts,
According to our customes; and all pray
The dew of grace, blesse our new Knight to day. Exeunt.
